author: By Mitch Smith
title: How do jury deliberations work?
description: The 12 jurors in Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial are to consider only the evidence presented in court as they work toward verdicts on five criminal counts that must each be decided unanimously.
content: For two weeks, jurors in Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial sat silently in a Kenosha, Wis., courtroom as witness after witness described the deadly chaos that played out in the city in August 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Disney Cruise Line will require all passengers ages 5 and older to be fully vaccinated.
description: The mandate will go into effect on Jan. 13 and will apply to sailings both in the United States and abroad.
content: Disney Cruise Line updated its immunization policy for guests on Wednesday, requiring all children over the age of 5 to be fully vaccinated against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: The DNA of Roma People Has Long Been Misused, Scientists Reveal
description: An op-ed in Nature calls for higher ethical standards in the usage and analysis of genetic information from the Romani, a marginalized group in Europe.
content: For decades, geneticists have collected the blood of thousands of Roma people, a marginalized group living in Europe, and deposited their DNA in public databases. The ostensible purpose of some of these studies was to learn more about the history and genetics of the Roma people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Ideal Scenario
description: Anne Grae Martin’s puzzle requires a flexible mind.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s a welcome return for Anne Grae Martin, who is making her second New York Times Crossword appearance, having debuted this year with a puzzle of “little red” things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Second U.S. Case of Monkeypox This Year Is Discovered in Maryland
description: Health officials said there was little risk that the virus, which causes a rare but potentially serious illness, would spread. Both cases this year were identified in travelers who had returned from Nigeria.
content: A case of monkeypox, a rare but potentially serious viral illness, was identified in a Maryland resident who had recently returned from Nigeria, making it the second case in the United States this year, health officials said. They said the risk that the virus would spread was low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Visions of a U.S. Computer Chip Boom Have Cities Hustling
description: Many local governments see a silver lining in the shortage of semiconductor chips that has contributed to a slowdown in the global economy.
content: TAYLOR, Texas — The shortage of computer chips has zapped energy from the global economy, punishing industries as varied as automakers and medical device manufacturers and contributing to fears about high inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Vaccines, Malcolm X, Adele: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Democrats Shouldn’t Panic. They Should Go Into Shock.
description: “No administration is going to thrive in that economic environment.”
content: The rise of inflation, supply chain shortages, a surge in illegal border crossings, the persistence of Covid, mayhem in Afghanistan and the uproar over “critical race theory” — all of these developments, individually and collectively, have taken their toll on President Biden and Democratic candidates, so much so that Democrats are now the underdogs going into 2022 and possibly 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $450,000 Homes in Arkansas, Texas and Minnesota
description: A 1903 Craftsman house in Little Rock, a 1930 bungalow in Dallas and a 1927 Tudor-style cottage in Minneapolis.
content: This house is in the heart of downtown Little Rock, a few blocks from the Arkansas Governor’s Mansion. A pharmacy and coffee shop are also within easy walking distance, and Arkansas Children’s Hospital is less than five minutes way by car. The riverfront, where attractions include a food hall, a farmers’ market and museums focused on Arkansas history, is about two miles away. Another major draw in this part of the city is the William J. Clinton Presidential Library and Museum, in a 30-acre public park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Idaho Lawmaker Is Censured for Doxxing Intern Who Reported Rape
description: Priscilla Giddings, an Idaho state representative, shared a student intern’s personal information after the teenager accused another lawmaker of rape.
content: An Idaho lawmaker who shared the personal information of a 19-year-old student intern online after the teenager accused another lawmaker of rape was formally censured by the Idaho House of Representatives on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Cy Young Awards Go to Pitchers Who Never Stopped Believing
description: Milwaukee’s Corbin Burnes and Toronto’s Robbie Ray had hit rock bottom before they worked their way up to stardom.
content: In 2019, Corbin Burnes had an 8.82 E.R.A. In 2020, Robbie Ray had a 6.62 E.R.A. and was traded in what amounted to a salary dump. On Wednesday, both pitchers proved that great stuff and a solid work ethic can win out eventually, as they were named the Cy Young Award winners for their leagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: They Love Crypto. They’re Trying to Buy the Constitution.
description: How a “financial flash mob” is trying to raise $20 million for a rare copy of the U.S. Constitution.
content: In September 1787, a group of delegates gathered in Philadelphia to sign the U.S. Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Platten
title: The Supply-Chain Crisis Is a Labor Crisis
description: Governments around the world have failed transport workers. But it’s not too late to help them.
content: From Los Angeles to Felixstowe, England; to Dubai, United Arab Emirates; to Shenzhen, China, the world is witnessing delays and shortages of everything from toys to turkeys. At the root of this crisis is a transport sector that is buckling under the strain of Covid-era conditions. Workers who drive the trucks, fly the planes and crew the ships responsible for moving all these goods — around $19 trillion of world trade annually — have been stretched to the breaking point. Governments have been too slow to act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir, Declan Walsh and Rick Gladstone
title: Sudanese forces kill 15 protesting the country’s recent coup, medics report.
description: The violence is shadowing Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s visit to Africa.
content: As if the war in Ethiopia were not enough, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s Africa visit is also shadowed by a military coup in Sudan, which has prompted weeks of protests drawing hundreds of thousands of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Researchers Identify Dozens of Native Students Who Died at Nebraska School
description: Using digitized records and newspaper clippings, researchers pieced together the history of the Genoa U.S. Indian Industrial School, a government-run institution that closed in 1934.
content: On the edge of town in Genoa, Neb., a stone monument serves as a gravestone on the grounds of a government-run boarding school for Native Americans that has been shuttered for almost a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Schweber and Glenn Thrush
title: Malcolm X’s confessed killer expresses support for the exonerations.
description: For decades, Mujahid Halim, 80, has admitted that he was one of the gunmen who assassinated the Black nationalist leader, but he swore his two co-defendants were innocent.
content: A man answering to the name Mujahid Halim responded to the exoneration of two men convicted alongside him in 1966 for Malcolm X’s murder with a relieved benediction, delivered quietly through a closed door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ed Bullins, Leading Playwright of the Black Arts Movement, Dies at 86
description: He wrote not for white or middle-class audiences, but for the strivers, hustlers and quiet sufferers whose struggles he sought to capture in searing works.
content: Ed Bullins, who was among the most significant Black playwrights of the 20th century and a leading voice in the Black Arts Movement of the 1960s and ’70s, died on Saturday at his home in Roxbury, Mass. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: The Tech Gifts That Are Hard to Buy This Holiday Season
description: The list of scarce gadgets is long, driven by a chip shortage. Don’t wait until Black Friday for the best deals.
content: It’s that time of the year when our inboxes are flooded with discounts galore for Black Friday, Cyber Week and all the sales promotions that follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Roger Federer to Miss Australian Open and All but Rules Out Wimbledon
description: Recovering from his fourth knee operation, Federer, at 40, has no illusions about winning a 21st major title. He wants to return for different reasons.
content: TURIN, Italy — With top-ranked Novak Djokovic and most of the world’s other top men’s tennis players gathered here for the ATP Finals, the absentee Roger Federer gave an update.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Jimmie Durham, Sculptor Who Explored Indigenous Themes, Dies at 81
description: He played with and challenged Native American stereotypes, then was criticized by Cherokee artists for tracing his ancestry to their tribe.
content: Jimmie Durham, an artist celebrated for incorporating traditional Native American imagery and materials into lively, unconventional sculptures before his claim of Cherokee ancestry was widely challenged, setting off an intense art-world debate over his authenticity, died on Wednesday in Berlin. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Requires Masks and Increases Coronavirus Testing for Thanksgiving
description: After N.F.L. cases more than doubled, the league strengthened its Covid-19 protocols and recommended teams help set up testing for families of players and team staff ahead of the holiday.
content: The N.F.L. strengthened its Covid-19 protocols as the number of positive cases rises across the country and people make plans to convene for Thanksgiving, and recommended facilitating testing for families of players and other employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Overdose Deaths Reached Record High as the Pandemic Spread
description: More than 100,000 Americans died from drug overdoses in the yearlong period ending in April, government researchers said.
content: Americans died of drug overdoses in record numbers as the pandemic spread across the country, federal researchers reported on Wednesday, the result of lost access to treatment, rising mental health problems and wider availability of dangerously potent street drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: A Green Light at the Window for Migrants
description: An unofficial network of local residents, activists and volunteer medics in Poland has been working to support those who have made it across from Belarus in freezing conditions.
content: NAREWKA, Poland — The green light in the window was easy to spot from the main road in Michalowo, a Polish town some 15 miles from the Belarusian border, where thousands of asylum seekers on their way to the European Union have been trapped in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Adam Satariano
title: Amazon, railing against high fees, will stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in Britain.
description: For years merchants have complained about transaction fees that eat into their revenue, but having Amazon take up the fight may ratchet up the pressure. The change will go into effect Jan. 19.
content: Amazon will stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in Britain from mid-January, the company said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Afrofuturist Room at the Met Redresses a Racial Trauma
description: “Before Yesterday We Could Fly,” a novel approach to the period room, threads together past, present and future. It focuses on Seneca Village, a Black community whose erasure still reverberates.
content: More than a year after the racial reckoning, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has created one of its most thoughtful reparations projects yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Pandemic Prompted People to Retire Early. Will They Return to Work?
description: Workers who retired because of Covid-19 are being enticed to return.
content: Retirement isn’t always forever. Over the course of a business cycle, about 20 percent of people are working within 12 months after they first report being retired, according to calculations by Goldman Sachs. The question now is how many people who took early retirement because of the Covid-19 pandemic will return to work. Will it be more than the usual one-fifth, or more, or about average? How “sticky” is retirement?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: C.D.C. Investigates Flu Outbreak at University of Michigan
description: There have been 528 cases of the flu on the university’s campus in Ann Arbor, a vast majority in students who have not had flu shots, school officials said.
content: Federal public health officials are investigating a “large and sudden” outbreak of the flu among students at the University of Michigan, the university announced this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: A Border Crisis
description: The situation at the Belarus-Poland border is unlike recent immigration crises.
content: A crowd of migrants trying to cross a border has come to seem appallingly familiar in recent years. We have seen masses of desperate people seek refuge in strange lands: Syrians escaping civil war, the Rohingya brutally driven from Myanmar, Afghans fleeing Taliban rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
title: The Wisconsin National Guard has been placed on standby ahead of the verdict.
description: Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin activated about 500 members of his state’s National Guard ahead of the verdict in Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial in Kenosha.
content: Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin activated about 500 members of his state’s National Guard ahead of the verdict in Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial in Kenosha. Officials said the troops would be placed on standby outside the city but would be ready to help if requested by local law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Catie Edmondson
title: House, Mostly Along Party Lines, Censures Gosar for Violent Video
description: The Arizona Republican is the first member of the House to be formally rebuked in more than a decade. He was also removed from two committees.
content: WASHINGTON — A bitterly divided U.S. House of Representatives voted narrowly on Wednesday to censure Representative Paul Gosar, Republican of Arizona, for posting an animated video that depicted him killing a Democratic congresswoman and assaulting President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: 300 Minutes a Week of Moderate Exercise May Help Ward Off Cancer
description: More than 46,000 cancers in America each year, or about 3 percent of cases, could be prevented by meeting physical activity guidelines.
content: More than 46,000 cancer cases in the United States might be prevented each year if almost all of us walked for about 45 minutes a day, according to an eye-opening new study of inactivity, exercise and malignancies. The study, which analyzed cancer incidence and the physical activity habits of nearly 600,000 American men and women in every state and the District of Columbia, found that about 3 percent of common cancers in the United States are strongly linked to inactivity. Something as simple as getting up and moving, the findings suggest, might help tens of thousands of us avoid developing cancer in the coming years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley
title: Script Supervisor Sues Alec Baldwin and Others in ‘Rust’ Shooting
description: A lawsuit filed by the supervisor, Mamie Mitchell, said an injury or death on the set was “a likely result” of the production’s failure to follow safety protocols.
content: A script supervisor for the movie “Rust” recalled Wednesday how she had been watching the actor Alec Baldwin practicing a move with a gun on the set in New Mexico last month, holding her script and checking photos on her iPhone to make sure that he was wearing the right shirt and vest, when she heard a loud blast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Travel Industry Takes Crucial First Step Toward Combating Climate Change
description: More than 300 travel companies, tourism boards and countries have signed the Glasgow Declaration on Climate Action in Tourism, the first step for a shared road map to cut carbon emissions.
content: The travel industry has reached a turning point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: A clash at the Belarusian-Polish border.
content: Hundreds of desperate and increasingly angry migrants, marooned at the border between Belarus and Poland, stampeded toward a frontier checkpoint yesterday, hurling stones and debris at Polish security personnel a few yards away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: 1,200 Miles From Kabul, a Celebrated Music School Reunites
description: Students and teachers of the Afghanistan National Institute of Music and their families, almost 200 in the past week, have fled to Qatar to escape Taliban restrictions on music.
content: The plane from Kabul touched down in Qatar around 6 p.m. on Tuesday. Two 13-year-old musicians — Zohra and Farida, a trumpet player and a violinist — disembarked and ran toward their teacher. Then, witnesses said, they began to cry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: ‘The Antelope Party’ Review: Friendship Is Magic, With Exceptions
description: Paranoia takes root among five friends who fear their “My Little Pony” role playing game is being targeted in this new play at the Wild Project.
content: Eric John Meyer’s “The Antelope Party,” a presentation of the Dutch Kills Theater Company that had its New York premiere recently at the Wild Project, uses a classic movie thriller structure to explore the potential real-world dangers of wish-fulfillment fantasy groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Inflation in Britain climbs to a 10-year high.
description: Prices rose 4.2 percent last month from a year earlier, more than double the Bank of England’s target.
content: Inflation in Britain rose to its highest level in nearly a decade in October after soaring energy prices hit household bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Hiroko Tabuchi
title: N.H.L. Partnership With Chemical Company Leaves Environmental Watchdogs Cold
description: A new report accuses the league of using its N.H.L. Green program to promote refrigerants that will contribute to global warming.
content: For over a decade the N.H.L. has promoted its commitment to the environment, using hockey’s birth on frozen ponds to connect the sport to the natural world and to portray its protection as a corporate imperative. But a new report questions that commitment and accuses the league of using its N.H.L. Green program to endorse refrigerants that will contribute to irreversibly warming the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Biden’s O.C.C. pick declares her support for capitalism and community banks.
description: Saule Omarova, a Cornell Law School professor, faces an unusually strident campaign against her nomination.
content: When she faces a room full of United States senators — some of whom have suggested she is a communist — Saule Omarova, President Biden’s pick to lead the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, will introduce herself by declaring that she loves two things: American capitalism and community banks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Manatees, Covid Dreams and Pinball
description: Each week, we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday, we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about manatees in Florida, reflect on their dream life, analyze an image about home and work, watch a film about youth culture and figure out what’s happening in a photograph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: How Much Does Having a ‘Dream Job' Matter to You?
description: Is our society too obsessed with work? How important is work to a meaningful life, in your opinion?
content: Note to teachers: To go with this question, we have a related Lesson of the Day based on the article “How Do They Say Economic Recovery? ‘I Quit.’” Some of the questions we pose below are also asked there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Adele Has a Lot of Big Feelings on ‘30’
description: The British superstar’s first album in six years deals with divorce and moving on, countering misery with virtuosity.
content: When a song makes you cry, are you crying for the singer? For the story the song tells? For the way it reflects your own experiences and memories? On “30,” her fourth album, Adele Adkins pushes for all of those at once, counting on her untrammeled musicality to pull together the empathy of pop with personal sympathy for a performer who’s grappling with motherhood, fame and changes of heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Alicia Parlapiano
title: Where Are Young People Most Optimistic? In Poorer Nations.
description: More than half of Americans, young and old, say children today will be less economically successful than their parents, a global survey shows.
content: Will the next generation do better than the one that came before? To young people in wealthier nations, that dream of upward mobility seems more like a story about the past than modern-day reality, according to a large new survey taken in 21 countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Risk for Leader of Belarus: Migrants He Lured May Want to Stay
description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, whom the E.U. accuses of engineering a migrant crisis on the border with Poland, could face a serious headache if asylum seekers try to stay in his country.
content: BRUZGI, Belarus — He has ruled with an iron fist for 27 years, surviving huge street protests, multiple rounds of Western sanctions and even alleged plots by his benefactor, Russia, to remove him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli
title: Young Dolph, Promising Memphis Rapper, Shot and Killed at 36
description: Known for collaborating widely and his deadpan bravado, his last solo album, “Rich Slave,” debuted at No. 4 on the Billboard chart last year.
content: Young Dolph, a deeply skilled Memphis rapper with deadpan bravado and a fierce independent streak who emerged as one of hip-hop’s most promising new stars in recent years, was killed Wednesday in a shooting in his hometown. He was 36.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: These are the people scholars believe really killed Malcolm X.
description: The review by the Manhattan district attorney’s office did not pin the crime on any other suspects. But scholars have formed their own conclusions.
content: For decades, the killing of Malcolm X has captivated the attention of scholars with a critical question: Were the wrong men convicted of the crime?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh
title: Blinken says fighting in Ethiopia ‘needs to stop.’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Was Fashion Doing at COP26?
description: Trading buzzwords, talking circularity and grappling with the role of clothes in the climate crisis.
content: The first time fashion got anywhere near an official United Nations climate conference like the one just held in Glasgow was in 2009. That was COP15 (COP stands for “conference of the parties”), and it was held in Copenhagen. I write “near” a COP because back then fashion was not considered central to the climate conversation. It wasn’t, somehow, serious enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Philip Margo of the Tokens, Who Sang of a Snoozing Lion, Dies at 79
description: His baritone contributed to the 1961 hit “The Lion Sleeps Tonight,” which became one of the most recognizable American pop songs ever.
content: Philip Margo, a member of the close-harmony group the Tokens, which earned enduring pop-music fame with the No. 1 hit “The Lion Sleeps Tonight” in 1961, died on Saturday in a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni, Hiroko Tabuchi, Albert Sun and Victor Moriyama
title: How Americans’ Appetite for Leather in Luxury SUVs Worsens Amazon Deforestation
description: An examination of Brazil’s immense tannery industry shows how hides from illegally deforested ranches can easily reach the global marketplace. In the United States, much of the demand for Brazilian leather comes from automakers.
content: BURITIS, Brazil — One morning this summer, Odilon Caetano Felipe, a rancher who raises cattle on illegally deforested land in the Amazon, met with a trader and signed over 72 newly fattened animals. With that stroke of the pen, Mr. Felipe gave his cattle a clean record: By selling them, he obscured their role in the destruction of the world’s largest rainforest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Park Avenue Armory Announces Futuristic New Season
description: Highlights include the North American premieres of Michel van der Aa’s opera “Upload” and Robert Icke’s production of “Hamlet.”
content: The Park Avenue Armory is taking a forward-looking approach in its 2022 season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Have Been Your Experiences With Substitute Teachers?
description: A shortage of substitute teachers has led to the cancellation of classes across the country. Does this make you appreciate these often undervalued educators more?
content: Across the country, schools are facing a shortage of substitute teachers. In Seattle, public schools were closed last Friday because there weren’t enough staff members to cover classes, while other school districts have been forced to return to remote learning temporarily. Is your school experiencing similar teacher shortages?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Supporters Appeal for Clemency for Death Row Inmate in Oklahoma
description: Hundreds of students walked out of schools and activists demonstrated at the State Capitol, urging Gov. Kevin Stitt to commute the sentence of Julius Jones, who is scheduled for execution on Thursday.
content: Hundreds of students walked out of schools and activists demonstrated outside the governor’s office on Wednesday in a final attempt to persuade Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma to grant clemency to a death-row inmate who is scheduled to be executed on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Vaccinated vs. Unvaccinated: Europe’s Covid Culture War
description: In pockets of Europe, vaccine resistance has become the long tail of the populist nationalist movements that shook up European politics for a decade.
content: ANNABERG-BUCHHOLZ, Germany — Sven Müller is proudly unvaccinated. He thinks Covid vaccines are neither effective nor safe but a way to make money for pharmaceutical companies and corrupt politicians who are taking away his freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Eric Krupke, Jessica Cheung, Lisa Tobin, Corey Schreppel and Chris Wood
title: The School Board Wars, Part 2
description: Meetings of the Central Bucks school board devolve into ugly fights and a bitter election is nearing. But what’s actually happening in classrooms?
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Germany’s anti-vaccine strongholds
content: In certain pockets of Europe, unvaccinated people are driving the latest surge in infections, filling strained hospital wards and sending governments scrambling to head off a fourth wave of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Who are the jurors in the Kyle Rittenhouse trial?
description: The jury is made up of seven women and five men. They began deliberating on Tuesday morning, and were to continue on Wednesday.
content: The fate of Kyle Rittenhouse was put in the hands of a jury that is made up of seven women and five men. They began deliberating on Tuesday morning, and continued on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Peloton and Zoom were two of the hot stocks of the pandemic. Now what?
description: Shares of companies like Peloton, the home fitness equipment maker, and Zoom Video, the online conference software that replaced face-to-face communications for countless schools and businesses, were darlings of the stock market for the better part of last year.
content: Shares of companies like Peloton, the home fitness equipment maker, and Zoom Video, the online conference software that replaced face-to-face communications for countless schools and businesses, were darlings of the stock market for the better part of last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Williams and Marian Carrasquero
title: An Indigenous Women’s Softball Team Beats Opponents, and Machismo
description: A Mayan team from a small community on the Yucatán Peninsula has caused a sensation by excelling as its athletes play barefoot and wear traditional dresses, breaking barriers with every game.
content: HONDZONOT, Mexico — Playing barefoot and wearing traditional Mayan dresses known as huipiles, the Little Devils softball team smashes hits, snags line drives and dashes around the bases in the sweltering heat of a Yucatán Peninsula jungle town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: The Making of Black Ivy Style
description: A new book examines how Black civil rights leaders, jazzmen, artists and writers rewrote the sartorial codes of a largely white elite.
content: It is a rare event when a volume comes along that skews our understandings of fashion as effectively as “Black Ivy: A Revolt in Style,” which will be published in the United States in December. Many images assembled in the coffee-table volume may be familiar — including iconic documents of the civil rights movement and magazine pictorials featuring literary idols like James Baldwin and the influential jazz album covers from the heyday of Blue Note Records — but it was not until Jason Jules assembled them in one place and under one rubric that a clear theme and thesis emerged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: U.S. Ties Jamaica, Stumbling Only Days After It Was Celebrating
description: Before a sparse crowd limited by pandemic regulations, the United States scored early but could not sustain the momentum from last week’s win over Mexico.
content: How do you keep your buzz going after an electrifying win over your fiercest rival in front of a raucous home crowd?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry Singer
title: Dave Frishberg, Writer of Songs Sardonic and Nostalgic, Dies at 88
description: A gifted jazz pianist and a singer with a limited range but a distinctive voice, he wrote mostly for grown-ups but reached his largest audience on “Schoolhouse Rock!”
content: Dave Frishberg, the jazz songwriter whose sardonic wit as a lyricist and melodic cleverness as a composer placed him in the top echelon of his craft, died on Wednesday in Portland, Ore. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Federal Bureau of Dirty Tricks
description: Donald Trump was right to fire James Comey.
content: This month’s bombshell indictment of Igor Danchenko, the Russian national who is charged with lying to the F.B.I. and whose work turns out to have been the main source for Christopher Steele’s notorious dossier, is being treated as a major embarrassment for much of the news media — and, if the charges stick, that’s exactly what it is.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Times Investigation Into Amazon Deforestation
description: An examination of Brazil’s tannery industry shows how leather seats in luxury SUVs are worsening forest destruction.
content: How do cow hides from illegal farms in the Amazon end up in American SUVs?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘Out of the Blue’: When Dennis Hopper Cast Himself as a Dad
description: As the director and star, Hopper delivered some wildly self-indulgent moments. But it’s Linda Manz, playing a troubled teenage girl, who stole the show.

author: By Laura May Todd
title: In Central Italy, a Dance Party by the Sea
description: Last month at La Posta Vecchia, the hotelier Marie-Louise Sciò threw a rollicking reunion for friends and family.
content: In 1960, the American-born oil tycoon J. Paul Getty purchased his dream vacation home in Italy. He could have opted for a palazzo in a bustling resort destination like Portofino or Capri but, perhaps unsurprisingly, given his obsession with ancient Rome — his collection of artifacts from the era included rare bronze statues and priceless friezes — Getty, who died in 1976, ended up in Ladispoli, a quiet seaside town just 30 miles outside of the Italian capital. That’s not to say his home there — a vast villa constructed in 1640 for guests of the noble Orsini clan, who lived in the 13th-century castle next door — lacked for grandeur. Indeed, at various points stretching back to the Roman Empire and up until World War II, when it was bombed heavily, this stretch of Tyrrhenian coastline, known for its tranquil beaches and temperate weather, was a premier destination for Rome’s elite. During the extensive renovations that Getty oversaw, builders unearthed the ruins of a second-century Roman villa, pieces of which are now displayed in the home’s basement-turned-antiquities gallery, though really the entire property is filled with museum-quality works.

title: Thor’s Exit: Noah Syndergaard Completes Deal With Angels
description: The oft-injured starter will try to re-establish himself in Los Angeles after a deal that netted the Mets a draft pick.
content: A healthy Noah Syndergaard may get back to the dominance he flashed as a young starting pitcher, but it won’t be with the Mets. The right-hander agreed to terms on a one-year deal with the Los Angeles Angels on Tuesday, joining a team that is long on star power but short on pitching.

title: A Crispy Upgrade for Cheese and Crackers
description: An unpretentious bar snack transformed into something sublime.
content: The bartender at McSorley’s Old Ale House wears a black garbage bag tied around his waist under his long white apron. When you order your ale there, all on draft, no bottles — you have a choice: light or dark, but whichever you order, they bring it two mugs at a time. It’s a standing-only bar often packed three deep, so with that much mug washing, that much brisk, agitated dunking into the hot soapy bins at his knees, the garbage bag makes sense.

description: The Build Back Better Act’s marquee provisions have been the focus, but Democrats have swept dozens of obscure measures and special interest breaks into the $1.85 trillion bill.
content: WASHINGTON — It includes a $4.1 billion tax break for people who buy electric bicycles, $2.5 billion for “tree equity,” another $2.5 billion to help “contingency fee” lawyers recoup their expenses and a long-sought tax break for producers of sound recordings.

author: By Jessica Grose
title: What if Your Kids Never Let You Sleep Again?
description: You can’t control your children’s sleep. And you probably don’t have to.
content: For about six months of this year, we had a glorious period when no child darkened our door at 3 a.m. But last month, for reasons obscure to me and my husband, either one or both of our kids started waking us up again in the middle of the night, multiple times a week. As far as I can tell, the younger one wakes up between sleep cycles, gets lonely and wants a cuddle. One of us takes her back to her bed, and she falls asleep immediately, then the lucky parent gets back into our bed — wide awake.

title: She Shaped the Sound of ‘Cowboy Bebop,’ Again
description: Yoko Kanno has become one of Japan’s foremost composers since she created the eclectic score for the anime series “Cowboy Bebop.” She returned for Netflix’s live-action version.
content: The anime series “Cowboy Bebop” debuted in Japan in 1998, combining futuristic space travel with Spaghetti Western grit and the slickness of film noir. In 2001, Cartoon Network aired an English dubbed version, introducing American audiences to the suave yet troubled bounty hunter Spike Spiegel and the ragtag crew of the spaceship Bebop.

description: Independent commissions to oversee the redrawing of electoral maps were thought to be the solution to an age-old problem. Instead, they have become bogged down in political trench warfare.
content: In Virginia, members of a bipartisan panel were entrusted with drawing a new map of the state’s congressional districts. But politics got in the way. Reduced to shouting matches, accusations and tears, they gave up.

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: In ‘Anna,’ the End of Adults, but Not the World

content: In the great television glut we’re living through, the hardest thing to find can be something that’s simply different — a series that doesn’t replay several other shows you recently binged. The Italian dystopian coming-of-age drama “Anna,” premiering Thursday on AMC+, fulfills that requirement, for better and for worse.
